column3: "If space and time do share some relational structure, then participants primed in the ego-moving spatial perspective should be able to reuse this perspective for time, and should thus think that the meeting will be on Friday. column3: "In the card problem, the outcome Òfive XÕs and one 0Ó is the most representative, because it matches the population proportion (see Kahneman & Tversky, 1972). H ence, by the representativeness heuristic, this outcome should be judged more frequent than the outcome Òsix xÕs and no 0,Ó contrary to the observed pattern of judgments in the path problem."
column4: "Number judging the one type of path more common than another"

column3: "Famous names are generally easier to recall. Hence, if frequency judgments are mediated by assessed availability, then a class consisting of famous names should be judged more numerous than a comparable class consisting of less famous names."
column4: "Participants were asked to recall whether men or women were more frequent in four different lists. The lists varied in whether the men or women were more famous (but actually slightly less frequent in the list)."
column5: "Among the 99 subjects who compared the frequency of men and women in the lists, 80 erroneously judged the class consist- ing of the more famous names to be more frequent (p < .OOl, by sign test)."
column16: "Results are given with a sign test, which the p-checker app cannot handle, so a Chi-Squared test was substituted"

column3: "This study essentially replicates ChapmanÕs (1967) original result and establishes the relation between judgments of the frequency of pairs and cued recall, i.e., the recall of the second word of the pair, called response, given the first, called stimulus."
column4: "Ps listened to series of word pairs, some of which were repeated. Highly Related (HR) and Unrelated (UR) pairs were repeated equally frequently"
column5: "A 2 X 2 analysis of variance showed that the HR pairs were judged more frequent than the UR pairs (t = 4.62, 67 df, p < .OOl), although they were, in fact, equally frequent. "

column3: "We predicted that high-power participants would be more likely than low-power participants to assume that the friend understood the sarcasm, even though a sarcastic interpretation depended on privileged background knowledge that the friend did not possess."

column3: " We expected that holding a heavy clipboard would lead to higher value judgments than holding a light clipboard."

column3: "we aimed to replicate previous findings that have supported a link between psychological and physical warmth "

column3: "Because previous studies suggested that agency does not influence perceptions of physical warmth, we predicted that agency (both compe- tence-related and dynamism-related qualities) will lead to lowest temperature estimates ... we expected that morally relevant traits may have a significant, but weaker effect on temperature perception."

column3: "We hypothesized that participants would be more likely to explicitly express an implicit preference for a man when their previous actions provided them with non- sexist credentials."

column3: "Study 2 provides a further test of the hypothesis that establishing credentials as a nonprejudiced person increases a person's will- ingness to express a prejudiced attitude."
column4: "2 (credentials) X 2 (type of prejudice) X 2 (gender) between subjects"

column3: "Stated more formally, a public image model of credentials predicts that estab- lishing credentials will only license people to give politically incorrect responses under same-audience conditions, whereas a self-image model of credentials predicts that credentials will li- cense people under both same-audience and different-audience conditions."
column4: "Same audience vs. No Credentials contrast"
column5: "The earlier findings were replicated in that participants who were given the opportunity to establish nonracist credentials favored a White more than did those who were not given the opportunity to estab- lish credentials (M = 4.9 vs. 4.2), f(19) = 2.2, p < .05."
